properties.project_description: This project is still at an early stage of designing the brief for the maintenance of Nitshill Woodland

A programme of tree planting will enhance and replace the current trees and woodland at Sighthill Transformation Regeneration Area (TRA). On the site currently there is 8.2ha of woodland with a high percentage of young trees that are not yet established. There are also 164 individual specimen trees. They will retain or plant 4.5ha of woodland on site afterwards and will be planting 1,195 specimen trees of different varieties across the site. This is part of a £250million urban development project funded by Glasgow City Council, Gl

A new native woodland is set to take root in Glasgow with 20,000 trees to be planted on former pastureland on the southern edge of the city. Backed by Glasgow City Council and Green Action Trust, the £125k project will see nine different species of native broadleaf trees planted across 15 hectares next to the Cart and Kittoch Valley Site of Special Scientific Interest, near to Carmunnock.

The tree density planting of this project was aprox. 1600 trees per hectare. The species of trees being planted at Cart and Kittoch are Common Alder (10%), Downy Birch (20%), Bird Cherry (10%), Holly (5%), Pendunculate Oak (10%), Sessile Oak (10%),Rowan (20%), Hawthorn (5%),Hazel (10%).

This project is about the maintenance of Crookston Wood, and further plantation of new woodlands. Maintenance activity in this area includes keeping woodland paths and scraps, and light thinning. New planting in this area will probably happen in 5-10 years. This project is part of the Woodland Management Park

This project is the first woodland of its size to be planted in Glasgow for generations and part of a wider woodland ambition known as the Cart & Kittoch. Lost Woods organized the planting with 135 primary schools across Glasgow to grow 17,000 sessile oak trees from acorns. The tree density was aprox. 1600 trees / ha
This project of planting of 1600 trees is sponsored by Lloyds. Planting of total of 1600 trees

As part of the compensatory planting for the Sighthill TRA. The GCC will plant 5.2 ha of woodland at Croftfoot. This site was selected as the tree planting will form a natural flood risk management intervention and will help to reduce the frequent flooding of residents in the Croftfoot area.

This project builds on this ambition to transform Vacant and Derelict Land (VDL) from industrial waste land to new innovative climate adaptation and mitigation centers. The project would be held by Glasgow City Council in collaboration with TreesAI. They propose to build on this ambition to transform VDL via the citizen-led preservation and stewardship preservation of existing pocket woodland.This is one of the proposed VDL sites located in Knowetap St, south of the railway track.

properties.project_name: Hillington and Cardoland Ph2 - Queensland Gardens
properties.project_description: This project fits within the taget area number 5502 from the "Flood Risk Management Plan" -Clyde and Loch Lomond Local Plan District. In November, phase 2 of the Hillington / Cardonald surface water management plan project - Queensland Gardens - won the Building with Nature National Award 2021 at the Landscape Institute awards. The project, being led by Southside Housing Association in partnership with Glasgow City Council flood reduction strategy, rainwater management on site will alleviate burden on city sewer system that is getting closer to capacity. With the formation of the basin and swales, the excavated soil will be kept on site to create small rolling hills to add to the playful aspect of each space, and create elevated viewing areas around the multi use games pitch. Caley Water undertook 1D/2D modelling of the minor and major drainage systems in InfoWorks ICM to understand existing and future flood risk in extreme rain events from the sewer system and overland flow.

properties.project_name: High Knightswood Surface Water Management Plan
properties.project_description:
The detailed design phase is ongoing for this project to deliver retrofit surface water management interventions in the High Knightswood area of Glasgow. This project is forecast to start on site early 2023 and is due to be completed late 2023. The introduction of an attenuation basin and conveyance swale in Temple Recreation Ground to provide surface water storage and conveyance along with associated new surface water network which will connect the attenuation basin into an existing surface water line/former watercourse, or combined sewer if necessary.
Localised road lowering on Cowdenhill Road/Rotherwood Avenue to provide an overland flow route for surface water and combined sewer exceedance flows into the attenuation basin (approx. £1.2 million).

This project fits within the taget area number 4300101 from the "Flood Risk Management Plan" -Clyde and Loch Lomond Local Plan District. The phase 1 and phase 2 have been completed. Phase 3 is about outline design for the raingardens and chanel realignment works and detailed design for a basin and raingardens in the kings park

This project fits within the taget area number 4300301 from the "Flood Risk Management Plan" -Clyde and Loch Lomond Local Plan District. The measures include ‘rain gardens’ on the roadside on Aikenhead Road and Kings Park Avenue. construction works would take place in the Croftfoot, King’s Park, Overwood Drive and Aikenhead Road areas and would include installation of drainage infrastructure, construction of rain-garden features, retrofitting of SuDS and associated public realm works

properties.project_name: Hillington and Cardonald Ph1 - Halfway Community Park
properties.project_description: Southside Housing Association has an established approach to monitoring and tracking the effectiveness of its services and regeneration activities.

properties.project_name: Eastern Springburn SWMP - Red Road TRA
properties.project_description: Part of Eastern Springburn Management Plan. Proposals involve the construction of a SuDS Wetland to serve the regeneration area. Also have funding from Sustrans to explore the feasibility for a new footpath linking the new SuDS wetland with an existing natural wetland and introducing new blue-green infrastructure to create a new green corridor.

properties.project_name: Hillington and Cardonadl Ph 3- Penilee Park
properties.project_description:
The application to NatureScot’s Nature Restoration Fund £115,000 
for grant funding was successful to support the delivery of the Hillington and
Cardonald Surface Water Management Plan - Phase 3 (Penilee) project. This
will enable a series of multi-functional sustainable drainage retrofit measures to
be introduced at Penilee Park.

GCC and engineering consultant Sweco are now progressing with a study to develop some feasible options as part of an overall plan to manage surface water throughout the area. Flooding happens when the river or the sewer network reach their capacity and runoff (from heavy rainfall) remains in the landscape. as more houses, businesses and amenities have been constructed in Castlemilk this has placed increasing pressure on the existing sewer network through the addition of more impermeable areas creating a greater likelihood of surface water flooding.
SuDS Planters, Swale, use of an existing amenity pond (approx.£1.1 million)

properties.project_name: Drumchapel Surface Water Management Plans Ph 4
properties.project_description: Enabled by funding from the Glasgow City Region City Deal (www.glasgowcityregion.co.uk), Drumchapel Surface Water Management Plan has been delivered by Glasgow City Council to create a series of series of embankments and storage areas along the line of the Garscadden Burn in the vicinity of Southdeen Avenue and Kinfauns Drive. The storage areas manage high flows during storm events, using the natural valley area as temporary floodplain storage to hold back water and reduce flood risk both upstream and downstream. This also reduces pressure on the combined sewer network, alleviating development constraints and ensuring drainage infrastructure is more resilient in a changing climate. Consideration of further interventions in the Drumchapel area is ongoing, as identified in the recently published Clyde and Loch Lomond Flood Risk Management Plan. Phase 1 (2014), funded by EDC in collaboration with Scottish Water, implemented SWM solutions in public open space, close to housing and schools. Sections of the local burn were de-culverted, and a skating pond reinstated to provide flood storage areas and enhance local biodiversity. Areas of raised ground aided management of above ground flows with play areas relocated and upgraded to deliver community benefits (Figure 3). Phase 2 (2016) was a £18m investment by Scottish Water to upgrade infrastructure and increase network capacity to address sewer flooding and open up development land to the north-west of the city. Phase 3 (2020) funding came via £5m from the Glasgow City Region City Deal and was used to further reduce flood risks in EDC and downstream city catchments.

At Cranhill Park, a SuDS basin has been retrofit, connecting to the Light Burn, to increase drainage capacity and enable sustainable regeneration in the area. The SuDS basin will also aid urban cooling and bring bio-diversity benefits to the existing greenspace. A further benefit from the project was the creation of new play facilities for a local primary school.

Glasgow City Council has approved funding (5 August) of up to £2.25million for the third phase of the Camlachie Burn Improvement Works, with this stage of the project enabling local regeneration by providing surface water drainage for key development sites including the proposed £60million Parkhead Health and Social Care Hub. These new works will also allow the Broad Street development by Clyde Gateway, and various social and private sector housing developments within the Camlachie Burn catchment: all of these are unable to proceed until sufficient drainage capacity is provided by the Camlachie Burn through delivery of the third phase of works. The works will also tackle the occurrence of flooding at Rigby Street and Shettleston Road – a problem for both the local community and commuters. The financial contribution of up to £2.25million from the council will – alongside £750,000 from the Health and Social Care Partnership (HSCP) as a contribution from the Parkhead Health and Social Care Hub – see the removal, treatment and disposal of silt and debris from the Camlachie Burn culvert between Shettleston Road and Biggar Street; and the installation of a penstock at the upstream end of the Camlachie Burn Overflow (CBO).  The council said that the works will be delivered within 12 months, with a site start expected in six months.
Proposals involve the construction of raingardens/swale and basin within the playground of the school. The cost is approx. £1.1 million.

A green infrastructure plan has been considered by Glasgow City Council as part of plans to regenerate North Maryhill to create an attractive, green, climate change resilient and connected neighbourhood.The Maryhill Transformational Regeneration Area (TRA) covers areas situated either side of Maryhill Road: to the north lies the North Maryhill/Gilshochill area, and to the south lies The Botany and Valley areas (Maryhill Locks), with recent development activity focused on the latter.The aim of this TRA – a partnership between Glasgow City Council, Glasgow Housing Association and the Scottish Government, with Maryhill Housing Association (MHA)

properties.project_name: Eastern Springburn SWMP Ph 1 - St. Martha's Primary School
properties.project_description: The proposed interventions include raingardens, along with downpipe artwork to connect roof runoff to the raingardens, and a detention basin. The detention basin will provide surface water storage both below ground and above ground during the large storm events. In dry weather and during light rain, the basin will remain empty of water, and available as a play area with seating formed around the edge. These interventions will reduce the speed at which surface water gets into the existing combined sewer network, which will help to reduce flood risk and improve watercourse water quality. Using blue-green infrastructure will provide additional benefits in terms of urban cooling, air quality, biodiversity and placemaking. The raingardens will also be used as an educational facility and pupils from the school helped influence the designs. Subject to the approval of City Deal capital funding, the project should start in Summer 2022.
properties.typology: raingardens, detention basin and rainwater collection

properties.project_description: Existing culvert renovation and sediment removal

properties.project_developer: Clyde Climate Forest - The Conservation Volunteers
properties.project_description: The Clyde Climate Forest (CCF) is planning a project to plant new trees in the urban area to increase the canopy cover in specific neighbourhoods in Glasgow. In Bridgeton and Dalmarnock the opportunity is to plant in aprox. 500 trees, 190 being stand trees, 10 being SuDS enabled street trees, and 300 being wips / saplings.
